title: Projects
text:
Projects
I am interested in a wide range of topics. Here are a few that I am currently working on:  


Can invertebrates feel pain?
Humans have long thought that pain and suffering was an experience unique to us. Recently, however, we have realised that other animals such as non-human mammals, birds, reptiles, fish, cephalopods, and crustaceans respond to noxious stimuli in a way that is consistent with the idea of pain and suffering. Insects are absent from this list, which is peculiar as they compose over 75% of all named species in the world and remain understudied in the field of pain and sentience. I am interested in exploring the idea of sentience and the subjective experience of pain in insects using their behavioural responses to noxious stimuli.  



INSERT PHOTO OF INSECT GROOMING HERE!


 


How and why insects jump
You might think that jumping is an easy behaviour to perform, but it is actually quite a challenge for insects, which are thousands of times smaller than we are. I am fascinated as to how insects jump frequently as they explore their world, catch prey, and escape predators despite the difficulty to execute such jumps. My findings were compiled in my Master of Research thesis with a cool discovery being that one group of Australian ants that were said to be incapable of jumping for the last 100 years were actually capable of leaping 3–4 cm to move about their environment efficiently.  



The first photograph of the Australian ant Myrmecia tarsata mid jump!

About Me
I’m Daniel, a PhD candidate from the University of Sydney, Australia, and this website is a test to slowly build my academic profile.   My interests lie in animal behaviour and evolution. More specifically, I love invertebrates and how they interact with the world around them depsite the obvious disadvantage of being small. Check out the projects tab to learn more about what I am interested in.
